title: Computer simulation tool for rhinoplasty planning
author: Ozkul T.; Ozkul M.H.
journal: Computers in Biology and Medicine
abstract: Rhinoplasty is a collection of surgical procedures performed on nose for the purpose of correcting functional and shape deformities. Nose is a facial feature which naturally draws attention during everyday contact. Any operation performed on nose has to blend well with the other facial features of the face. For this reason rhinoplasty is a type of surgery which requires artistic skills from surgeon as well as surgical skills. In this paper we present an artistic simulation tool which manipulates the shape of the nose on the bases of rhinoplasty procedures to be used during the surgery. Unlike other artistic simulation tools which can modify shape with no constraints, this tool simulates the effect of individual operations. Simulation tool can be valuable only if it predicts the outcome of the surgery with accuracy. Ultimately the outcome of the simulation depends largely on the experience of the surgeon. This is also the case with the tool presented in this study, so with experience the tool can be useful for predicting outcome more and more accurately. In this paper, the mechanical model of the nose and tools used for simulation are discussed. The simulation results are compared with actual rhinoplasty results to see the fidelity of the approach. A flowchart of the decision process and how rhinoplastic simulation together with the ideal nose data can be used to aid actual rhinoplastic surgery is given at the end. © 2003 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

title: 3D-guided face manipulation of 2D images for the prediction of post-operative outcome after cranio-maxillofacial surgery
author: Andlauer, Robin and Wachter, Andreas and Schaufelberger, Matthias and Weichel, Frederic and K{\"u}hle, Reinald and Freudlsperger, Christian and Nahm, Werner
journal: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: Accurate prediction of post-operative facial appearance is crucial for cranio-maxillofacial surgery planning and patient communication. Existing methods often rely on 3D facial data, which are not always available in clinical practice. In this paper, we propose a novel framework for 3D-guided face manipulation of 2D images to predict post-operative outcomes. Our approach reconstructs a 3D face model from a single 2D image, simulates surgical procedures on the 3D model, and then generates a manipulated 2D image reflecting the predicted post-operative appearance. The framework integrates a parametric 3D morphable model with a deep learning-based image synthesis network, ensuring both geometric accuracy and photorealistic rendering. Extensive experiments on clinical datasets demonstrate that our method achieves superior performance in predicting post-operative facial changes compared to state-of-the-art techniques, providing a valuable tool for surgical planning and patient consultation.

title: An Advanced Human Bone Tissue Culture Model for the Assessment of Implant Osteointegration In Vitro
author: Maglio M.; Fini M.; Sartori M.; Codispoti G.; Borsari V.; Dallari D.; Ambretti S.; Rocchi M.; Tschon M.
journal: International Journal of Molecular Sciences
abstract: Osteointegration is a key factor for the long-term success of orthopedic and dental implants. However, the current in vitro models used to study osteointegration lack the complexity of human bone tissue, limiting their predictive value. Here, we present an advanced human bone tissue culture model that mimics the in vivo environment for the assessment of implant osteointegration. Human trabecular bone explants were cultured under dynamic conditions in a perfusion bioreactor system, maintaining cell viability and bone matrix integrity over 28 days. Titanium implant discs were inserted into the bone explants, and osteointegration was evaluated by histological, biochemical, and mechanical analyses. Our model demonstrated active bone remodeling and new bone formation at the bone-implant interface, closely resembling physiological osteointegration processes. This advanced in vitro model provides a valuable platform for preclinical testing of implant materials and surface modifications, potentially reducing the need for animal experiments and accelerating implant development.

title: Analysis of In Vivo Skin Anisotropy Using Elastic Wave Measurements and Bayesian Modelling
author: Nagle M.; Price S.; Trotta A.; Destrade M.; Fop M.; Ní Annaidh A.
journal: Annals of Biomedical Engineering
abstract: Skin anisotropy is a key biomechanical property that influences the mechanical response of skin to external forces. In this study, we present a novel approach to analyze in vivo skin anisotropy by combining elastic wave measurements with Bayesian modeling. Elastic waves were generated and measured on the skin surface to capture directional mechanical properties. A Bayesian framework was employed to model the anisotropic behavior, allowing for probabilistic estimation of skin stiffness parameters and their uncertainties. Our results demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach in characterizing skin anisotropy non-invasively, providing insights into the directional dependence of skin mechanics. This methodology has potential applications in dermatology, cosmetic science, and the development of skin-mimicking materials.

title: 3D-printing of the elbow in complex posttraumatic elbow-stiffness for preoperative planning, surgery-simulation and postoperative control
author: Grunert R.; Winkler D.; Frank F.; Moebius R.; Kropla F.; Meixensberger J.; Hepp P.; Elze M.
journal: 3D Printing in Medicine
abstract: Background: Complex posttraumatic elbow stiffness is a challenging condition for the surgeon. The aim of this study was to evaluate the use of 3D printing of the elbow in complex posttraumatic elbow stiffness for preoperative planning, surgery simulation, and postoperative control. Methods: We present a case series of patients with complex posttraumatic elbow stiffness who underwent 3D printing of the elbow based on CT scans. The 3D printed models were used for preoperative planning, surgical simulation, and postoperative evaluation. Results: The use of 3D printed models allowed for better visualization of the complex anatomy and pathology, facilitated surgical planning and simulation, and improved communication with patients. Postoperative control using 3D models helped in assessing the surgical outcome. Conclusions: 3D printing of the elbow is a valuable tool in the management of complex posttraumatic elbow stiffness, enhancing preoperative planning, surgical simulation, and postoperative control.

title: Automated calculation of ontology-based planning proposals: An application in reconstructive oral and maxillofacial surgery
author: Hagen N.; Weichel F.; Kühle R.; Knaup P.; Freudlsperger C.; Eisenmann U.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Computer-assisted planning and navigation have become essential tools in reconstructive oral and maxillofacial surgery. However, the planning process remains time-consuming and requires expert knowledge. This study presents an automated approach for generating planning proposals based on an ontology that models the surgical domain, including anatomical structures, surgical procedures, and planning constraints. The ontology-based system integrates patient-specific data and surgical goals to automatically calculate feasible surgical plans. The approach was implemented and evaluated in the context of reconstructive oral and maxillofacial surgery, demonstrating its potential to support surgeons by providing consistent and comprehensive planning proposals, thereby improving planning efficiency and quality.

title: Bone stress relaxation in press-fit femoral knee implant fixation: A combined experimental and computational analysis

author: Gersie T.; Bitter T.; Freeman R.; Verdonschot N.; Janssen D.

title: A prediction method and evaluation for assessing guide-supported dental implant accuracy
author: Xu L.; Wu J.; Chen L.; Gao H.; Zhu X.; Yang G.; Chen Y.
journal: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
abstract: This study proposes a novel prediction method to assess the accuracy of guide-supported dental implant placement. By integrating preoperative planning data with postoperative imaging, the method quantifies deviations in implant positioning. The evaluation involved a series of clinical cases where the predicted accuracy was compared against actual outcomes, demonstrating the method's reliability and potential to enhance surgical precision. The findings suggest that this approach can serve as a valuable tool for clinicians to predict and improve implant placement accuracy, ultimately contributing to better patient outcomes in dental implantology.

title: Unsupervised generative model for simulating post-operative double eyelid image
author: Wu R.; Liao S.; Dai P.; Han F.; Kui X.; Song X.
journal: Physical and Engineering Sciences in Medicine
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH

title: Simulation of Postoperative Facial Appearances via Geometric Deep Learning for Efficient Orthognathic Surgical Planning
author: Ma L.; Xiao D.; Kim D.; Lian C.; Kuang T.; Liu Q.; Deng H.; Yang E.; Liebschner M.A.K.; Gateno J.; Xia J.J.; Yap P.-T.
journal: IEEE Transactions on Medical Imaging
doi: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc.
abstract: Orthognathic surgery aims to correct dentofacial deformities by repositioning the jawbones, which significantly impacts patients’ facial appearances. Accurate prediction of postoperative facial appearances is crucial for surgical planning and patient communication. Traditional methods rely on biomechanical models or statistical shape models, which can be computationally intensive or limited in capturing complex facial deformations. In this paper, we propose a novel geometric deep learning framework to simulate postoperative facial appearances efficiently. Our approach leverages graph convolutional networks to model the 3D facial mesh and predict postoperative deformations based on preoperative scans and planned surgical movements. We validate our method on a clinical dataset of orthognathic surgery patients, demonstrating superior accuracy and computational efficiency compared to existing techniques. The proposed framework facilitates interactive surgical planning and enhances patient understanding by providing realistic postoperative facial simulations.

title: Impact of fractured tibia implant fixation devices on bone stiffness during bending test
author: Ketata H.; Hfaiedh N.; Kanhonou M.; Badreddine H.
journal: Medical Engineering and Physics
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Anomaly Detection via Progressive Reconstruction and Hierarchical Feature Fusion
author: Liu F.; Zhu X.; Feng P.; Zeng L.
journal: Sensors (Basel, Switzerland)
abstract: Anomaly detection is a crucial task in computer vision, aiming to identify abnormal patterns that deviate from normal data. In this paper, we propose a novel anomaly detection framework based on progressive reconstruction and hierarchical feature fusion. Our method progressively reconstructs input images through multiple stages, capturing both global and local features to enhance the representation of normal patterns. Additionally, hierarchical feature fusion integrates multi-level features to improve the discrimination between normal and abnormal regions. Extensive experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach achieves superior performance compared to state-of-the-art methods, highlighting its effectiveness and robustness in detecting anomalies.

title: Augmented reality simulation framework for minimally invasive orthopedic surgery
author: Cangelosi A.; Riberi G.; Titolo P.; Salvi M.; Molinari F.; Ulrich L.; Vezzetti E.; Agus M.; Calì C.

author: Soltanihafshejani N.; Bitter T.; Verdonschot N.; Janssen D.

title: An interactive augmented reality software for facial reconstructive surgeries
author: Guo W.; Forte V.; Davies J.C.; Kahrs L.A.
journal: Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine
abstract: This paper presents an interactive augmented reality (AR) software designed to assist surgeons during facial reconstructive surgeries. The software integrates preoperative 3D models with real-time intraoperative data, providing enhanced visualization and guidance. By overlaying virtual anatomical structures onto the patient's face, the system aims to improve surgical accuracy and outcomes. The AR platform supports interactive manipulation, allowing surgeons to adjust and verify surgical plans dynamically. Validation through clinical case studies demonstrates the software's potential to facilitate complex facial reconstructions, reduce operative time, and enhance precision. This work contributes to the advancement of computer-assisted surgical tools by combining AR technology with user-friendly interfaces tailored for facial reconstructive procedures.

title: 3d-printed sacral reconstruction prosthesis from multiscale topology optimization: A comprehensive numerical assessment of mechanical stability
author: Jitkla N.; Pinyonitikasem A.; Wiwatsuwan P.; Pairojboriboon S.; Promoppatum P.
journal: Computers in Biology and Medicine
