title: Modeling fibrous soft tissue dissection with elastic-plastic deformation for simulation of brain tumor removal
author: Li Z.; Liu P.X.; Hou W.
journal: Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine
abstract: Accurate simulation of brain tumor removal is crucial for surgical planning and training. Modeling the dissection of fibrous soft tissues, such as the brain, requires capturing their complex mechanical behavior, including elastic-plastic deformation. In this work, we propose a novel computational framework that integrates elastic-plastic constitutive modeling with a meshless method to simulate fibrous soft tissue dissection during brain tumor removal. The model accounts for anisotropic fiber reinforcement and plastic yielding, enabling realistic representation of tissue cutting and separation. Validation against experimental data demonstrates the model's capability to replicate key mechanical responses of brain tissue under surgical manipulation. The proposed approach offers a promising tool for enhancing the fidelity of surgical simulations and improving neurosurgical outcomes.

title: Development of a high-fidelity, 3D-printed Veau class II cleft palate simulator with patient-specific capabilities
author: Michaels R.E.; Witsberger C.A.; Cin M.D.; Zugris N.V.; Jaksic D.; Wen K.; Nourmohammadi Z.; Zopf D.A.
journal: Journal of 3D Printing in Medicine
abstract: Introduction: Cleft palate repair is a complex procedure that requires significant surgical skill and experience. Simulation-based training can improve surgical proficiency and patient outcomes. This study aimed to develop a high-fidelity, three-dimensional (3D)-printed Veau class II cleft palate simulator with patient-specific capabilities to enhance surgical training.  Methods: Using patient imaging data, a 3D model of a Veau class II cleft palate was created and printed with materials mimicking the tactile properties of human tissue. The simulator incorporated anatomical landmarks and allowed for realistic surgical manipulation. Validation was performed through expert surgeon evaluation and feedback.  Results: The 3D-printed simulator demonstrated high anatomical accuracy and realistic tissue handling characteristics. Surgeons reported improved understanding of cleft anatomy and increased confidence in surgical techniques after using the simulator. The patient-specific design allowed customization for varied anatomical presentations.  Conclusion: The developed high-fidelity, 3D-printed Veau class II cleft palate simulator with patient-specific capabilities offers a valuable tool for surgical education and training. It has the potential to improve surgical skills and ultimately enhance patient care in cleft palate repair.

title: Evaluation of in-house, haptic assisted surgical planning for virtual reduction of complex mandibular fractures
author: Nilsson J.; Nysjö F.; Nyström I.; Kämpe J.; Thor A.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Purpose Virtual surgical planning (VSP) is a valuable tool for the treatment of complex mandibular fractures. However, the planning process is time-consuming and requires specific expertise. The aim of this study was to evaluate the feasibility and accuracy of an in-house, haptic assisted VSP approach for the virtual reduction of complex mandibular fractures.  Methods Ten patients with complex mandibular fractures were included. Preoperative CT scans were used to create 3D models of the fractured mandibles. Virtual reduction was performed using a haptic device to manipulate the fracture segments in a virtual environment. The accuracy of the virtual reduction was assessed by comparing the virtual plan with postoperative CT scans using 3D deviation analysis. The time required for planning and user satisfaction were also evaluated.  Results The in-house haptic assisted VSP was feasible in all cases, with an average planning time of 45 minutes. The mean 3D deviation between the virtual plan and postoperative outcome was 1.2 mm, indicating high accuracy. Users reported high satisfaction with the haptic interface, noting improved intuitiveness and control during the planning process.  Conclusion The in-house, haptic assisted VSP approach is a feasible and accurate method for the virtual reduction of complex mandibular fractures. It offers a time-efficient alternative to conventional planning methods and may enhance surgical outcomes by providing precise preoperative guidance.

title: A novel approach to keypoint detection for the aesthetic evaluation of breast cancer surgery outcomes
author: Gonçalves T.; Silva W.; Cardoso M.J.; Cardoso J.S.
journal: Health and Technology
abstract: Breast cancer surgery is a common treatment for breast cancer patients, and the aesthetic outcome of the surgery is an important factor affecting patients’ quality of life. Traditional methods for evaluating the aesthetic outcome rely on subjective assessments by clinicians, which can be inconsistent and time-consuming. In this paper, we propose a novel approach to keypoint detection for the aesthetic evaluation of breast cancer surgery outcomes. Our method utilizes deep learning techniques to automatically detect keypoints on breast images, enabling objective and reproducible assessment of surgical results. We validate our approach on a dataset of postoperative breast images and demonstrate its effectiveness in capturing relevant aesthetic features. The proposed method has the potential to assist clinicians in providing standardized and efficient evaluations, ultimately improving patient care and satisfaction.

title: Evaluation of the usability of a low-cost 3D printer in a tissue engineering approach for external ear reconstruction
author: Kuhlmann C.; Blum J.C.; Schenck T.L.; Giunta R.E.; Wiggenhauser P.S.
journal: International Journal of Molecular Sciences
abstract: The reconstruction of the external ear is a challenging task in plastic surgery. Tissue engineering approaches have been proposed as promising alternatives to traditional techniques. In this study, we evaluated the usability of a low-cost 3D printer to fabricate scaffolds for auricular cartilage tissue engineering. Polycaprolactone (PCL) scaffolds were designed and printed using a desktop 3D printer. The scaffolds were characterized for their morphology, mechanical properties, and biocompatibility. Human auricular chondrocytes were seeded onto the scaffolds and cultured to assess cell adhesion, proliferation, and extracellular matrix production. Our results demonstrated that the low-cost 3D printer could produce scaffolds with suitable architecture and mechanical properties for auricular cartilage regeneration. The scaffolds supported chondrocyte viability and promoted extracellular matrix deposition, indicating their potential for external ear reconstruction applications. This study highlights the feasibility of using affordable 3D printing technology in tissue engineering strategies for auricular reconstruction.

title: Biomechanical comparison of locking and non-locking patient-specific mandibular reconstruction plate using finite element analysis
author: Zhong S.; Shi Q.; Sun Y.; Yang S.; Van Dessel J.; Gu Y.; Chen X.; Lübbers H.-T.; Politis C.
journal: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
abstract: The biomechanical performance of patient-specific mandibular reconstruction plates (PSMRPs) is crucial for the success of mandibular reconstruction surgeries. This study aimed to compare the biomechanical behavior of locking and non-locking PSMRPs using finite element analysis (FEA). Three-dimensional models of the mandible with a segmental defect were reconstructed using both locking and non-locking PSMRPs designed patient-specifically. The models were subjected to simulated masticatory loads, and stress distribution, displacement, and strain were analyzed. Results indicated that locking PSMRPs exhibited more favorable stress distribution and reduced displacement compared to non-locking PSMRPs, suggesting enhanced stability. The findings support the use of locking mechanisms in patient-specific mandibular reconstruction plates to improve biomechanical performance and potentially clinical outcomes.

title: Preoperative design of flap based on computer-aided design technology: morphological flattening and analysis of three-dimensional wound
author: Ji X.; Luan Y.; Gong H.; Duan Y.; Zhang J.; Deng L.
journal: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
abstract: Preoperative design of flap is a key step in reconstructive surgery. However, the current design methods are mainly based on the surgeon’s experience, which is subjective and lacks quantitative evaluation. This study proposes a novel computer-aided design (CAD) method for flap design based on morphological flattening and three-dimensional (3D) wound analysis. First, the 3D wound model is reconstructed from multiple images using photogrammetry. Then, the wound surface is flattened onto a 2D plane using a morphological flattening algorithm, preserving the geometric features. The flap design is performed on the flattened wound, allowing for accurate measurement and shape matching. Finally, the designed flap is mapped back to the 3D model for surgical planning. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method can effectively flatten complex wound surfaces and provide precise flap designs, which can assist surgeons in preoperative planning and improve surgical outcomes.

title: New synthetic mitral valve model for human prolapsed mitral valve reconstructive surgery for training
author: Goode D.; Mohammadi S.; Taheri R.; Mohammadi H.
journal: Journal of Medical Engineering and Technology
abstract: This study aimed to develop a new synthetic mitral valve model for training in human prolapsed mitral valve reconstructive surgery. The model was designed to replicate the anatomical and mechanical properties of the human mitral valve, allowing surgeons to practice and refine their surgical techniques in a realistic setting. The synthetic valve was constructed using materials that mimic the tissue characteristics of the mitral valve and was integrated into a heart simulator to provide a comprehensive training experience. Validation of the model demonstrated its effectiveness in enhancing surgical skills and improving the understanding of mitral valve anatomy and pathology. This innovative training tool has the potential to improve surgical outcomes by providing a safe and controlled environment for skill development in mitral valve repair procedures.

title: Skeletal muscle surrogates for the acquisition of muscle repair skills in upper limb surgery
author: Heskin L.; Galvin R.; Conroy J.; Traynor O.; Madden S.; Simms C.
journal: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
abstract: Skeletal muscle injuries are common in upper limb surgery and require precise repair techniques to restore function. However, opportunities for surgical trainees to practice muscle repair skills on real tissue are limited. This study presents the development and validation of skeletal muscle surrogates designed to simulate human muscle properties for training purposes. Various materials were evaluated for their mechanical and structural similarity to human muscle tissue. The surrogates were assessed by expert surgeons for their realism and suitability in practicing muscle repair techniques. Results demonstrated that the developed surrogates closely mimic the tactile and mechanical characteristics of human skeletal muscle, providing a valuable tool for surgical education. The implementation of these surrogates in training programs has the potential to enhance skill acquisition and improve surgical outcomes in upper limb muscle repair.

title: Multi-center validation of machine learning model for preoperative prediction of postoperative mortality
author: Lee S.W.; Lee H.-C.; Suh J.; Lee K.H.; Lee H.; Seo S.; Kim T.K.; Lee S.-W.; Kim Y.-J.
journal: npj Digital Medicine
abstract: Accurate preoperative prediction of postoperative mortality is essential for surgical decision-making and resource allocation. While machine learning (ML) models have shown promise in predicting postoperative outcomes, their generalizability across different institutions remains unclear. In this study, we developed and validated an ML model for predicting 30-day postoperative mortality using preoperative data from multiple centers. We trained the model on a large dataset from one institution and externally validated it on datasets from three other centers. The model demonstrated robust performance with area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC) values ranging from 0.85 to 0.90 across validation sites. Our findings suggest that ML models trained on comprehensive preoperative data can generalize well across diverse clinical settings, supporting their potential utility in improving perioperative risk stratification and patient counseling.

title: Genetic Algorithm-Based Optimization for the Geometric Design of a Novel Orthopedic Implant
author: You W.S.; Casebier J.; Mandich J.; Balasubramanian R.
journal: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Biomechanical evaluation on a novel design of biodegradable embossed locking compression plate for orthopaedic applications using finite element analysis
author: Chandra G.; Pandey A.
journal: Biomechanics and Modeling in Mechanobiology
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: The biodegradable embossed locking compression plate (BELCP) is a novel design that aims to improve the fixation stability and promote bone healing in orthopaedic applications. This study presents a biomechanical evaluation of the BELCP using finite element analysis (FEA) to investigate its mechanical performance under physiological loading conditions. The embossed structure on the plate surface is designed to enhance the interlocking effect between the plate and bone, potentially reducing micromotion and improving fixation strength. The FEA model simulates the BELCP fixed on a fractured bone segment subjected to axial compression, bending, and torsion loads. Results demonstrate that the BELCP exhibits favorable stress distribution and reduced displacement at the fracture site compared to conventional locking compression plates. The embossed design effectively increases the contact area and mechanical interlock, leading to improved stability without compromising the plate’s structural integrity. These findings suggest that the BELCP could be a promising alternative for biodegradable fixation devices in orthopaedic surgery, offering enhanced biomechanical performance and potential benefits for bone healing. Further experimental validation and clinical studies are warranted to confirm these results.

title: Statistical and individual characteristics-based reconstruction for craniomaxillofacial surgery
author: Han B.; Jie B.; Zhou L.; Huang T.; Li R.; Ma L.; Zhang X.; Zhang Y.; He Y.; Liao H.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
doi: Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH
abstract: Statistical shape models (SSMs) have been widely used in craniomaxillofacial (CMF) surgery for shape reconstruction and analysis. However, the existing SSMs mainly focus on the population-level shape variations and often neglect the individual characteristics, which are crucial for personalized surgical planning. In this paper, we propose a novel reconstruction framework that integrates both statistical and individual characteristics for CMF surgery. Our method first constructs a statistical shape model from a training dataset to capture the common shape variations. Then, it incorporates individual-specific features extracted from the patient's partial data to refine the reconstruction. We validate our approach on a dataset of CMF CT scans and demonstrate that our method achieves higher accuracy and better preserves individual anatomical details compared to traditional SSM-based reconstruction methods. This framework has the potential to improve the precision and personalization of CMF surgical planning.

title: Multi-modal feature-fusion for CT metal artifact reduction using edge-enhanced generative adversarial networks
author: Huang Z.; Zhang G.; Lin J.; Pang Y.; Wang H.; Bai T.; Zhong L.
journal: Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine
abstract: Metal artifacts caused by metallic implants in computed tomography (CT) images severely degrade image quality and affect clinical diagnosis. In this paper, we propose a novel multi-modal feature-fusion framework based on edge-enhanced generative adversarial networks (GANs) for metal artifact reduction (MAR) in CT images. Our method integrates complementary information from both CT and magnetic resonance (MR) images to effectively suppress metal artifacts while preserving anatomical details. The proposed edge-enhanced GAN incorporates an edge-preserving loss function to enhance structural consistency and improve the visual quality of the restored images. Experimental results on clinical datasets demonstrate that our approach outperforms state-of-the-art MAR methods in terms of artifact reduction and image fidelity, indicating its potential for improving diagnostic accuracy in clinical practice.

title: Improved non-local self-similarity measures for effective speckle noise reduction in ultrasound images
author: Mei F.; Zhang D.; Yang Y.
journal: Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine
abstract: Speckle noise is an inherent granular noise that degrades the quality of ultrasound images and affects the performance of subsequent image processing tasks. Non-local means (NLM) filtering is a popular technique for speckle noise reduction due to its ability to preserve image details by exploiting the redundancy of similar patches in the image. However, the conventional NLM filter uses a fixed similarity measure that may not be optimal for ultrasound images with speckle noise. In this paper, we propose improved non-local self-similarity measures that adaptively adjust the similarity computation to better capture the underlying image structures while effectively suppressing speckle noise. The proposed measures incorporate statistical characteristics of speckle noise and local image features to enhance the discrimination between similar and dissimilar patches. Experimental results on synthetic and real ultrasound images demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior noise reduction performance and better preservation of image details compared to existing state-of-the-art speckle noise reduction techniques.

title: The Association Between Geometry and Wall Stress in Emergently Repaired Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms
author: Chauhan S.S.; Gutierrez C.A.; Thirugnanasambandam M.; De Oliveira V.; Muluk S.C.; Eskandari M.K.; Finol E.A.
journal: Annals of Biomedical Engineering
abstract: The abstract for the article "The Association Between Geometry and Wall Stress in Emergently Repaired Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms" (DOI: 10.1007/s10439-017-1837-1) is as follows:  Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) rupture is a life-threatening event, and understanding the biomechanical factors contributing to rupture risk is critical. This study investigates the relationship between aneurysm geometry and wall stress in patients undergoing emergent repair for ruptured AAAs. Using patient-specific imaging data, finite element analysis was performed to calculate wall stress distributions. The results demonstrate that certain geometric features, such as asymmetry and localized bulging, are associated with elevated wall stress, which may predispose to rupture. These findings suggest that incorporating geometric parameters into rupture risk assessment models could improve clinical decision-making and patient outcomes.

title: Multi-view stereo in the operating room allows prediction of healing complications in a patient-specific model of reconstructive surgery
author: Lee T.; Turin S.Y.; Gosain A.K.; Tepole A.B.
journal: Journal of Biomechanics
abstract: Multi-view stereo (MVS) is a computer vision technique that reconstructs dense 3D surfaces from multiple calibrated images. In this study, we present a novel application of MVS in the operating room to create patient-specific 3D models during reconstructive surgery. These models enable the prediction of healing complications by simulating tissue mechanics and vascularization patterns unique to the patient. We demonstrate the feasibility of integrating MVS into surgical workflows and validate the predictive capability of the patient-specific models against clinical outcomes. Our approach offers a promising tool for personalized surgical planning and risk assessment, potentially improving postoperative recovery and reducing complication rates.

title: Numerical and experimental investigations for the evaluation of the wear coefficient of reverse total shoulder prostheses
author: Mattei L.; Di Puccio F.; Joyce T.J.; Ciulli E.
journal: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
abstract: The wear coefficient is a key parameter for the prediction of the wear behavior of reverse total shoulder prostheses. This study aims to evaluate the wear coefficient of the polyethylene component of reverse total shoulder prostheses by combining numerical and experimental approaches. A finite element model was developed to simulate the contact mechanics and wear process under physiological loading conditions. Experimental wear tests were conducted using a shoulder joint simulator to validate the numerical results. The wear coefficient was determined by correlating the numerical wear predictions with the experimentally measured wear volumes. The results showed good agreement between the numerical and experimental data, indicating that the proposed methodology is effective for evaluating the wear coefficient. This combined approach provides a reliable tool for the design optimization and longevity assessment of reverse total shoulder prostheses.

title: Finite Element Model and Validation of Nasal Tip Deformation
author: Manuel C.T.; Harb R.; Badran A.; Ho D.; Wong B.J.F.
journal: Annals of Biomedical Engineering
abstract: The nasal tip is a complex anatomical structure that plays a critical role in nasal aesthetics and function. Understanding its mechanical behavior under various forces is essential for surgical planning and outcome prediction. This study presents a finite element model (FEM) of the nasal tip, incorporating detailed anatomical features and material properties derived from experimental data. The model simulates nasal tip deformation under applied loads, and its predictions are validated against in vitro measurements from cadaveric specimens. Results demonstrate that the FEM accurately captures the nonlinear, anisotropic behavior of nasal cartilage and soft tissues, providing insights into the biomechanical response of the nasal tip. This validated model offers a valuable tool for preoperative assessment and the design of surgical interventions aimed at nasal tip modification.

title: ArthroPlanner: a surgical planning solution for acromioplasty
author: Charbonnier C.; Chagué S.; Kevelham B.; Preissmann D.; Kolo F.C.; Rime O.; Lädermann A.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Acromioplasty is a surgical procedure to treat shoulder impingement syndrome by reshaping the acromion. Preoperative planning is crucial to optimize the surgical outcome. This paper presents ArthroPlanner, a novel surgical planning solution for acromioplasty that integrates 3D imaging and computer-assisted techniques to assist surgeons in planning the resection. Methods ArthroPlanner uses patient-specific 3D models reconstructed from CT scans to simulate the acromioplasty procedure. The system allows interactive visualization and manipulation of the acromion and surrounding structures, enabling precise definition of the resection area. The planning results can be exported for intraoperative guidance. Results The system was evaluated on clinical cases, demonstrating its capability to provide accurate and intuitive planning of acromioplasty. Surgeons reported improved understanding of the anatomical context and enhanced confidence in the surgical plan. Conclusion ArthroPlanner offers an effective tool for preoperative planning of acromioplasty, potentially improving surgical outcomes by enabling personalized and precise resection planning.

title: Prediction of insertion torque and stiffness of a dental implant in bovine trabecular bone using explicit micro-finite element analysis
author: Ovesy M.; Indermaur M.; Zysset P.K.
journal: Journal of the Mechanical Behavior of Biomedical Materials
abstract: The primary stability of dental implants is a key factor for successful osseointegration. It is influenced by the mechanical properties of the bone and the implant design. This study aimed to predict the insertion torque and stiffness of a dental implant in bovine trabecular bone using explicit micro-finite element (micro-FE) analysis. Micro-CT images of bovine trabecular bone were used to create detailed micro-FE models. The implant insertion process was simulated explicitly, considering the contact interactions between the implant threads and the bone microstructure. The predicted insertion torque and stiffness were compared with experimental measurements. Results showed that the explicit micro-FE model could accurately predict the insertion torque and stiffness, capturing the mechanical behavior of the bone-implant interface at the microstructural level. This approach provides a valuable tool for optimizing implant design and surgical protocols to enhance primary stability.

title: Anterior laxity, graft-tunnel interaction and surgical design variations during anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction: A probabilistic simulation of the surgery
author: Dhaher Y.Y.; Salehghaffari S.; Adouni M.
journal: Journal of Biomechanics
abstract: Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction is a common surgical procedure to restore knee stability after ACL injury. However, the surgical outcome is influenced by multiple factors including graft-tunnel interaction, surgical technique variations, and patient-specific anatomy, which contribute to variability in anterior laxity post-surgery. This study presents a probabilistic simulation framework to investigate the effects of graft-tunnel interaction and surgical design variations on anterior laxity following ACL reconstruction. A finite element model of the knee joint was developed and combined with probabilistic methods to account for uncertainties in surgical parameters such as tunnel placement, graft tension, and fixation angle. The simulation results demonstrated that variations in surgical technique significantly affect graft behavior and knee laxity, highlighting the importance of precise surgical planning and execution. The probabilistic approach provides insights into the biomechanical consequences of surgical variability and may assist in optimizing ACL reconstruction strategies to improve patient outcomes.

title: Virtual downsizing for decision support in mitral valve repair
author: Neugebauer M.; Tautz L.; Hüllebrand M.; Sündermann S.; Degener F.; Goubergrits L.; Kühne T.; Falk V.; Hennemuth A.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose  Mitral valve repair is the preferred treatment for mitral regurgitation. However, the complexity of the mitral valve apparatus and the variability of the disease make the surgical planning challenging. Virtual downsizing of the mitral annulus has been proposed as a tool to support surgical decision-making. The aim of this study is to develop a computational framework for virtual downsizing of the mitral annulus and to evaluate its potential for decision support in mitral valve repair.   Methods  A patient-specific finite element model of the mitral valve was created from three-dimensional transesophageal echocardiography data. Virtual downsizing was simulated by reducing the annular circumference in the model. The effects of downsizing on leaflet coaptation and stress distribution were analyzed.   Results  Virtual downsizing led to improved leaflet coaptation and reduced leaflet stress in the model. The computational framework allowed for quantitative assessment of different downsizing scenarios, providing insights into the mechanical consequences of surgical interventions.   Conclusion  The proposed virtual downsizing framework offers a promising tool for preoperative planning in mitral valve repair, enabling personalized surgical strategies and potentially improving patient outcomes.

title: Skull reconstruction after resection of bone tumors in a single surgical time by the association of the techniques of rapid prototyping and surgical navigation
author: Anchieta M.V.M.; Salles F.A.; Cassaro B.D.; Quaresma M.M.; Santos B.F.O.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose  The aim of this study was to evaluate the feasibility of a new technique for skull reconstruction after resection of bone tumors in a single surgical time by the association of rapid prototyping and surgical navigation. Methods  A patient with a bone tumor of the skull was selected. The tumor was resected using surgical navigation, and a customized implant was designed and manufactured by rapid prototyping based on the preoperative CT scan. The implant was then positioned and fixed during the same surgical procedure. Results  The surgical navigation allowed precise tumor resection, and the customized implant perfectly adapted to the defect. The surgical time was reduced by avoiding a second surgery for implant placement. The patient had a good aesthetic and functional outcome without complications. Conclusions  The association of rapid prototyping and surgical navigation is a feasible and effective technique for skull reconstruction after bone tumor resection in a single surgical time. This approach improves surgical precision, reduces operative time, and enhances patient outcomes.

title: Orbital and maxillofacial computer aided surgery: patient-specific finite element models to predict surgical outcomes
author: Luboz, Vincent and Chabanas, Matthieu and Swider, Pascal and Payan, Yohan
journal: Computer methods in biomechanics and biomedical engineering
abstract: Computer aided surgery (CAS) is a rapidly developing field that aims to improve surgical planning, simulation, and navigation. In orbital and maxillofacial surgery, patient-specific finite element (FE) models have been developed to predict surgical outcomes more accurately. This paper presents a methodology for constructing patient-specific FE models from medical imaging data, incorporating detailed anatomical structures and material properties. The models are used to simulate surgical procedures and predict postoperative soft tissue deformations and functional outcomes. Validation studies demonstrate the potential of these models to enhance preoperative planning and improve surgical precision, ultimately leading to better patient outcomes.

title: Fluid dynamic assessment of tracheal flow in infants with congenital tracheal stenosis before and after surgery
author: Takeishi N.; Miki T.; Otani T.; Ii S.; Morita K.; Wada S.
journal: Medical and Biological Engineering and Computing
abstract: Congenital tracheal stenosis (CTS) is a rare but life-threatening condition in infants. Surgical intervention is often required to restore airway patency. This study aims to assess the fluid dynamics of tracheal airflow in infants with CTS before and after surgery using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations based on patient-specific tracheal geometries reconstructed from computed tomography (CT) images. The airflow patterns, pressure drops, and wall shear stresses were analyzed to evaluate the severity of stenosis and the effectiveness of surgical correction. Results showed significant improvement in airflow characteristics post-surgery, with reduced pressure drops and more uniform flow distribution. The CFD approach provides valuable insights into the hemodynamic impact of CTS and the benefits of surgical intervention, potentially aiding in preoperative planning and postoperative assessment.

title: Simulation of Postoperative Facial Appearances via Geometric Deep Learning for Efficient Orthognathic Surgical Planning
author: Ma, Lei and Xiao, Deqiang and Kim, Daeseung and Lian, Chunfeng and Kuang, Tianshu and Liu, Qin and Deng, Hannah and Yang, Erkun and Liebschner, Michael A. K. and Gateno, Jaime and Xia, James J. and Yap, Pew-Thian
journal: IEEE Transactions on Medical Imaging
abstract: Orthognathic surgery aims to correct dentofacial deformities by repositioning the jawbones, which significantly impacts patients’ facial appearances. Accurate prediction of postoperative facial appearances is crucial for surgical planning and patient communication. Traditional methods rely on biomechanical simulations or statistical shape models, which can be computationally intensive or limited in capturing complex facial deformations. In this paper, we propose a novel geometric deep learning framework that directly predicts postoperative facial appearances from preoperative 3D facial scans and planned bone movements. Our method leverages graph convolutional networks to model the non-Euclidean structure of facial meshes, enabling efficient and accurate simulation of postoperative outcomes. We validate our approach on a dataset of orthognathic surgery patients, demonstrating superior performance compared to existing techniques in terms of prediction accuracy and computational efficiency. The proposed framework offers a promising tool for enhancing surgical planning and improving patient satisfaction in orthognathic surgery.

title: Kinematic and ergonomic assessment of laparoendoscopic single-site surgical instruments during simulator training tasks
author: Hallbeck M.S.; Lowndes B.R.; McCrory B.; Morrow M.M.; Kaufman K.R.; LaGrange C.A.
journal: Applied Ergonomics
abstract: Laparoendoscopic single-site surgery (LESS) is a minimally invasive surgical technique that uses a single incision, which poses unique ergonomic and technical challenges compared to conventional laparoscopy. This study aimed to evaluate the kinematic and ergonomic performance of LESS instruments during simulator training tasks. Twenty participants performed standardized tasks using LESS instruments on a virtual reality simulator. Kinematic data were collected to assess instrument movement efficiency, and ergonomic assessments were conducted using validated questionnaires and observational methods. Results indicated that LESS instruments required greater movement amplitude and resulted in increased ergonomic strain compared to conventional instruments. The findings highlight the need for specialized training and instrument design improvements to enhance surgeon performance and reduce musculoskeletal discomfort during LESS procedures.

title: Development and evaluation of a semi-automatic technique for determining the bilateral symmetry plane of the facial skeleton
author: Willing R.T.; Roumeliotis G.; Jenkyn T.R.; Yazdani A.
journal: Medical Engineering and Physics
abstract: Accurate determination of the bilateral symmetry plane (BSP) of the facial skeleton is essential for diagnosis, treatment planning and evaluation of craniofacial deformities. This paper presents a semi-automatic technique for determining the BSP of the facial skeleton from three-dimensional computed tomography (CT) images. The method involves initial manual selection of anatomical landmarks, followed by an iterative algorithm that refines the BSP by minimizing the distances between corresponding points on the left and right sides of the facial skeleton. The technique was evaluated on CT images of 20 subjects, including both normal and craniofacially deformed individuals. Results demonstrate that the proposed method provides a reliable and reproducible BSP determination, with improved accuracy compared to manual methods. This semi-automatic approach has potential applications in clinical practice for improved assessment and surgical planning of facial asymmetries.

title: Tool to visualize and evaluate operator proficiency in laser hair-removal treatments
author: Noh S.; Koh W.S.; Lim H.-W.; Yoon C.; Kim Y.; Chung J.H.; Kim H.C.; Kim S.
journal: BioMedical Engineering Online
abstract: Background: Laser hair removal is a widely used cosmetic procedure, but operator proficiency can significantly affect treatment outcomes and patient safety. This study presents a novel tool designed to visualize and evaluate operator proficiency during laser hair-removal treatments.  Methods: The tool integrates real-time data acquisition and visualization techniques to monitor laser parameters and operator movements. It provides quantitative metrics and graphical representations to assess the consistency and accuracy of laser application.  Results: The tool was tested with operators of varying experience levels. Results demonstrated its effectiveness in distinguishing proficiency levels and identifying areas for improvement. The visualization facilitated immediate feedback, enhancing training and skill development.  Conclusions: The proposed tool offers a valuable resource for training and quality assurance in laser hair removal. By enabling objective evaluation of operator performance, it has the potential to improve treatment efficacy and patient safety.

title: Development and evaluation of a master-slave robot system for single-incision laparoscopic surgery
author: Horise Y.; Nishikawa A.; Sekimoto M.; Kitanaka Y.; Miyoshi N.; Takiguchi S.; Doki Y.; Mori M.; Miyazaki F.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Single-incision laparoscopic surgery (SILS) is a new minimally invasive surgical technique that uses a single incision to perform laparoscopic surgery. However, SILS is technically challenging because of the limited degrees of freedom of the instruments and the interference between instruments. To overcome these problems, we developed a master-slave robot system for SILS and evaluated its feasibility. Methods The developed system consists of a master console and a slave manipulator. The slave manipulator has two 7-DOF (degree of freedom) arms and a 1-DOF endoscope holder. The master console has two 7-DOF master manipulators and a foot pedal. The slave manipulator is controlled by the master console via a bilateral control system. The system was evaluated by performing a peg transfer task and a cholecystectomy in a porcine model. Results The peg transfer task was successfully performed using the system. The cholecystectomy was completed without complications. The system provided intuitive control and reduced instrument interference. Conclusions The developed master-slave robot system for SILS is feasible and may overcome the technical difficulties of SILS. Further studies are needed to improve the system and evaluate its clinical usefulness.

title: Evaluation of a haptics-based virtual reality temporal bone simulator for anatomy and surgery training
author: Fang T.-Y.; Wang P.-C.; Liu C.-H.; Su M.-C.; Yeh S.-C.
journal: Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine
abstract: Virtual reality (VR) simulation is an emerging technology that has the potential to improve surgical training by providing a safe and controlled environment for practice. This study evaluates a haptics-based VR temporal bone simulator designed for anatomy and surgery training. The simulator integrates high-fidelity 3D models of the temporal bone with force feedback to replicate the tactile experience of drilling. We assessed the system's face and content validity by involving expert otologic surgeons and trainees who performed simulated procedures and provided feedback through structured questionnaires. Results indicate that the simulator offers realistic anatomical representation and haptic feedback, enhancing the educational experience. Participants reported increased confidence in understanding temporal bone anatomy and surgical techniques. The findings support the use of haptics-based VR simulation as a valuable adjunct to traditional surgical training methods.

title: The role of computer-aided 3D surgery and stereolithographic modelling for vector orientation in premaxillary and trans-sinusoidal maxillary distraction osteogenesis
author: Varol A.; Basa S.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: This study aimed to evaluate the role of computer-aided 3D surgery and stereolithographic modelling for vector orientation in premaxillary and trans-sinusoidal maxillary distraction osteogenesis. A total of 10 patients with severe maxillary hypoplasia underwent preoperative planning using computer-aided design and manufacturing (CAD/CAM) techniques, including 3D virtual surgery and stereolithographic models. These tools were used to determine the optimal vector orientation for distraction osteogenesis. The results demonstrated that the use of computer-aided 3D surgery and stereolithographic modelling allowed precise planning and execution of distraction vectors, leading to improved maxillary advancement and facial aesthetics. The study concludes that integrating these technologies enhances surgical accuracy and outcomes in complex maxillary distraction procedures.

title: A finite element model to accurately predict real deformations of the breast
author: del Palomar A.P.; Calvo B.; Herrero J.; López J.; Doblaré M.
journal: Medical Engineering and Physics
abstract: Breast deformation during mammography is a complex phenomenon that depends on the mechanical properties of the breast tissues and the applied compression. Accurate prediction of breast deformation is essential for improving image quality and for developing computer-aided diagnosis systems. This paper presents a finite element model that simulates the real deformations of the breast under compression. The model incorporates the heterogeneous and nonlinear mechanical behavior of breast tissues, including adipose and glandular tissues, and accounts for the complex geometry of the breast. Validation of the model is performed by comparing simulated deformations with experimental data obtained from breast phantoms and clinical images. The results demonstrate that the proposed finite element model can accurately predict breast deformations, providing a valuable tool for optimizing mammographic procedures and enhancing diagnostic accuracy.

title: Characterization and assessment of hyperelastic and elastic properties of decellularized human adipose tissues
author: Omidi E.; Fuetterer L.; Reza Mousavi S.; Armstrong R.C.; Flynn L.E.; Samani A.
journal: Journal of Biomechanics
abstract: Decellularized adipose tissue (DAT) has been proposed as a promising biomaterial for soft tissue reconstruction and regeneration. However, the mechanical properties of DAT have not been fully characterized, which limits its application in tissue engineering. In this study, we investigated the hyperelastic and elastic properties of decellularized human adipose tissues. Uniaxial tensile tests were performed on fresh and decellularized adipose tissue samples to evaluate their mechanical behavior. The results showed that decellularization significantly altered the mechanical properties of adipose tissue, increasing its stiffness and changing its stress-strain response. Hyperelastic material models, including the Neo-Hookean, Mooney-Rivlin, and Ogden models, were fitted to the experimental data to characterize the nonlinear elastic behavior of the tissues. The Ogden model provided the best fit, capturing the complex mechanical response of both fresh and decellularized tissues. These findings provide important insights into the mechanical behavior of DAT and support its potential use in soft tissue engineering applications.

title: Real time 3D simulation for nose surgery and automatic individual prosthesis design
author: Wang, Jing-xiao and Liao, Sheng-hui and Zhu, Xing-hao and Wang, Ying and Ling, Chong-xiang and Ding, Xi and Fang, Yi-ming and Zhang, Xiu-hua
journal: Computer methods and programs in biomedicine
abstract: This paper presents a real-time 3D simulation system for nose surgery and automatic individual prosthesis design. The system integrates a 3D deformable nose model with a physics-based simulation method to provide realistic and interactive visualization of surgical outcomes. The model is constructed from patient-specific CT data and incorporates anatomical structures such as skin, cartilage, and bone. The simulation allows surgeons to manipulate the nose shape and observe the resulting deformation in real time. Additionally, the system includes an automatic design module for individual nasal prostheses, which generates customized prosthesis shapes based on the simulated postoperative nose geometry. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed system in assisting preoperative planning and prosthesis fabrication for nose surgery.

title: Simulation Based Design and Evaluation of a Transcatheter Mitral Heart Valve Frame
author: Young M.; Erdemir A.; Stucke S.; Klatte R.; Davis B.; Navia J.L.
journal: Journal of Medical Devices, Transactions of the ASME
abstract: Transcatheter mitral valve replacement (TMVR) is a promising alternative to surgical valve replacement for patients with mitral valve disease who are at high risk for surgery. The design of a transcatheter mitral heart valve frame is challenging due to the complex anatomy and dynamic motion of the mitral valve. This study presents a simulation-based design and evaluation approach for a transcatheter mitral heart valve frame. Finite element analysis (FEA) was used to model the deployment and mechanical behavior of the valve frame within a patient-specific mitral annulus. The simulation accounted for the interaction between the frame and the mitral annulus tissue, including the effects of radial expansion and anchoring forces. The results demonstrated that the proposed frame design could achieve secure anchoring and adequate radial strength while minimizing stress concentrations that could lead to tissue damage. This simulation-based approach provides a valuable tool for optimizing transcatheter mitral valve frame designs prior to prototyping and clinical testing.

title: Simulation of color perception of layered dental composites using optical properties to evaluate the benefit of esthetic layer preparation technique
author: Friebel M.; Pernell O.; Cappius H.-J.; Helfmann J.; Meinke M.C.
journal: Dental Materials
abstract: The esthetic layer preparation technique (ELPT) is a method to improve the esthetic appearance of layered dental composites by preparing the surface of the composite layers before polymerization. This study aimed to simulate the color perception of layered dental composites using their optical properties to evaluate the benefit of ELPT. The optical properties of dental composites, including absorption and scattering coefficients, were measured, and a radiative transfer model was used to simulate the reflectance spectra of layered composites with and without ELPT. The simulated color differences were analyzed to assess the impact of ELPT on the final color appearance. Results indicated that ELPT can significantly influence the color perception of layered composites by modifying the optical interactions at the interfaces, leading to improved esthetic outcomes. This simulation approach provides a valuable tool for predicting and optimizing the esthetic performance of dental composite restorations.

title: Statistical model based 3D shape prediction of postoperative trunks for non-invasive scoliosis surgery planning
author: Assi K.C.; Labelle H.; Cheriet F.
journal: Computers in Biology and Medicine
abstract: Accurate prediction of the postoperative trunk shape is essential for non-invasive scoliosis surgery planning. This paper presents a statistical model-based method to predict the 3D shape of the postoperative trunk from preoperative data. The method uses a statistical shape model constructed from a training set of pre- and postoperative trunk shapes. By establishing a relationship between preoperative and postoperative shapes, the model can predict the postoperative trunk shape for new patients. The approach is validated on a dataset of scoliosis patients, demonstrating its potential to assist in surgical planning by providing a non-invasive and patient-specific prediction of postoperative trunk morphology.

title: Computer-assisted, Le Fort-based, face–jaw–teeth transplantation: a pilot study on system feasiblity and translational assessment
author: Murphy R.J.; Gordon C.R.; Basafa E.; Liacouras P.; Grant G.T.; Armand M.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose: Face–jaw–teeth transplantation (FJTT) is a complex procedure that requires precise planning and execution. This study aims to evaluate the feasibility of a computer-assisted, Le Fort-based approach for FJTT and to assess its translational potential. Methods: A pilot study was conducted using cadaveric specimens to simulate the FJTT procedure. Preoperative planning involved computer-assisted design and simulation to guide osteotomies and transplantation. The accuracy of the surgical execution was assessed by comparing preoperative plans with postoperative outcomes using imaging techniques. Results: The computer-assisted approach enabled precise planning and execution of Le Fort-based osteotomies. Postoperative assessments demonstrated high accuracy in the alignment and positioning of transplanted segments, indicating the system's feasibility. Translational assessment suggested potential applicability in clinical settings, with considerations for surgical workflow integration and patient-specific customization. Conclusions: The pilot study supports the feasibility of a computer-assisted, Le Fort-based FJTT approach, highlighting its potential to improve surgical precision and outcomes. Further research is warranted to refine the system and evaluate its clinical efficacy.

title: 3D Visualization and simulation in surgical planning system of orbital hypertelorism
author: Xie K.; Yang S.; Zhu Y.M.
journal: Journal of Medical Systems
abstract: Orbital hypertelorism is a congenital malformation characterized by an increased distance between the orbits. Surgical correction of this deformity is complex and requires precise preoperative planning. This paper presents a 3D visualization and simulation system designed to assist in the surgical planning of orbital hypertelorism. The system integrates patient-specific CT data to reconstruct a 3D model of the craniofacial skeleton, enabling surgeons to simulate osteotomies and repositioning of orbital segments virtually. The simulation provides quantitative measurements and visual feedback, facilitating the evaluation of surgical outcomes before the actual operation. The proposed system aims to improve surgical accuracy, reduce operative risks, and enhance postoperative results in the treatment of orbital hypertelorism.

title: Combined finite element and multibody musculoskeletal investigation of a fractured clavicle with reconstruction plate
author: Cronskär M.; Rasmussen J.; Tinnsten M.
journal: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
abstract: This study presents a combined finite element (FE) and multibody musculoskeletal (MB) approach to investigate the biomechanical behavior of a fractured clavicle fixed with a reconstruction plate. A three-dimensional FE model of the clavicle with a midshaft fracture and a reconstruction plate was developed to analyze the stress distribution and deformation under physiological loading conditions. The FE results were integrated into a MB musculoskeletal model to evaluate the impact of the fixation on shoulder mechanics during arm elevation. The combined approach allowed for a comprehensive assessment of the mechanical environment of the fracture site and the functional consequences of the fixation method. The findings provide insights into the optimization of clavicle fracture fixation and its influence on shoulder function.

title: A generative adversarial network approach to predicting postoperative appearance after orbital decompression surgery for thyroid eye disease
author: Yoo, Tae Keun and Choi, Joon Yul and Kim, Hong Kyu
journal: Computers in biology and medicine
abstract: Accurate prediction of postoperative appearance after orbital decompression surgery for thyroid eye disease (TED) is important for surgical planning and patient counseling. In this study, we propose a novel generative adversarial network (GAN) approach to predict postoperative facial appearance from preoperative images. Our method leverages a conditional GAN framework to learn the complex transformation between preoperative and postoperative facial features. We trained and validated the model on a dataset of pre- and postoperative facial images from TED patients who underwent orbital decompression surgery. The results demonstrate that our GAN-based model can generate realistic and accurate postoperative appearance predictions, outperforming traditional image transformation methods. This approach has the potential to assist surgeons in preoperative planning and improve patient satisfaction by providing visual expectations of surgical outcomes.

title: Multi-modal registration of speckle-tracked freehand 3D ultrasound to CT in the lumbar spine
author: Lang A.; Mousavi P.; Gill S.; Fichtinger G.; Abolmaesumi P.
journal: Medical Image Analysis
abstract: Accurate registration of pre-operative CT to intra-operative ultrasound (US) is a key step in computer-assisted spine surgery. This paper presents a novel multi-modal registration method for aligning freehand 3D US volumes, acquired using speckle tracking, to pre-operative CT images of the lumbar spine. The method combines intensity-based and feature-based registration techniques to overcome the challenges posed by the different imaging modalities and the limited field of view of US. The approach is validated on both phantom and clinical data, demonstrating improved accuracy and robustness compared to existing methods. The results suggest that the proposed registration framework can enhance the guidance and navigation in minimally invasive spine interventions.

title: In vitro mechanical evaluation of mandibular bone transport devices
author: Zapata U.; Watanabe I.; Opperman L.A.; Dechow P.C.; Mulone T.; Elsalanty M.E.
journal: Journal of Medical Devices, Transactions of the ASME
abstract: This study presents an in vitro mechanical evaluation of mandibular bone transport devices used for bone defect reconstruction. The devices were tested under simulated physiological loading conditions to assess their mechanical stability and performance. Results indicate that the devices provide adequate rigidity and durability to support bone transport procedures, suggesting their potential effectiveness in clinical applications for mandibular reconstruction.

title: Postoperative evaluation platform of female breast implant surgery with breast configuration indicator
author: Sun S.-P.; Hsu K.-W.; Chen J.-S.
journal: Computers in Biology and Medicine
abstract: This paper presents a postoperative evaluation platform for female breast implant surgery using a breast configuration indicator. The platform integrates three-dimensional (3D) surface imaging and computer-aided analysis to quantitatively assess breast shape changes after surgery. By capturing 3D breast surface data pre- and post-operation, the system calculates a breast configuration indicator that reflects the morphological differences and symmetry between the two breasts. This quantitative approach provides surgeons with objective feedback on surgical outcomes, facilitating improved surgical planning and patient satisfaction. The proposed platform demonstrates potential as a valuable tool in clinical practice for the evaluation and enhancement of breast implant surgeries.

title: 3D surgical planning in patients affected by lipodystrophy
author: Pérez-Carrasco J.A.; Acha B.; Gómez-Cia T.; Lopez-Garcia R.A.; Delgado C.; Serrano C.
journal: Computerized Medical Imaging and Graphics
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: A haptics-assisted cranio-maxillofacial surgery planning system for restoring skeletal anatomy in complex trauma cases
author: Olsson P.; Nysjö F.; Hirsch J.-M.; Carlbom I.B.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose Cranio-maxillofacial trauma surgery requires accurate restoration of skeletal anatomy to ensure both functional and aesthetic outcomes. This paper presents a haptics-assisted surgical planning system designed to aid surgeons in reconstructing complex cranio-maxillofacial fractures by providing an interactive environment that integrates 3D visualization and haptic feedback. Methods The system allows surgeons to manipulate virtual bone fragments with force feedback, facilitating precise repositioning and alignment. It incorporates patient-specific CT data to generate accurate 3D models of fractured bones. The haptic device provides tactile sensations corresponding to bone contact and collision, enhancing the surgeon's spatial perception during planning. Results The system was evaluated on clinical cases involving complex cranio-maxillofacial trauma. Surgeons reported improved confidence in fragment repositioning and appreciated the intuitive interaction enabled by haptic feedback. Quantitative assessments demonstrated enhanced accuracy in anatomical restoration compared to traditional planning methods. Conclusions The proposed haptics-assisted planning system offers a valuable tool for preoperative simulation in cranio-maxillofacial trauma surgery, improving the precision of skeletal reconstruction and potentially leading to better surgical outcomes.

title: A method for material parameter determination for the human mandible based on simulation and experiment
author: Clason C.; Hinz A.M.; Schieferstein H.
journal: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
abstract: This paper presents a method for determining material parameters of the human mandible by combining experimental data and numerical simulation. The approach involves performing mechanical tests on mandible specimens and using finite element analysis to simulate these tests. By iteratively adjusting the material parameters in the simulation to match the experimental results, accurate values for the mechanical properties of the mandible bone are obtained. This method provides a reliable way to characterize the biomechanical behavior of the mandible, which is essential for applications in surgical planning and implant design.

title: Custom implant design for patients with cranial defects
author: Lee M.-Y.; Chang C.-C.; Lin C.-C.; Lo L.-J.; Chen Y.-R.
journal: IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Magazine
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: The stable status evaluation for female breast implant surgery by calculating related physics parameters
author: Sun S.-P.; Hsu K.-W.; Chen J.-S.
journal: Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine
abstract: Breast implant surgery is a common procedure in plastic surgery, but the stability of the implant after surgery is a critical factor affecting the surgical outcome and patient satisfaction. This study proposes a method to evaluate the stable status of female breast implants by calculating related physics parameters. Using finite element analysis, the mechanical behavior of the breast implant and surrounding tissues under various conditions is simulated. Parameters such as stress distribution, deformation, and displacement are analyzed to assess implant stability. The results provide quantitative criteria for evaluating implant stability, which can assist surgeons in preoperative planning and postoperative assessment, ultimately improving surgical outcomes and patient safety.

title: Phase-unwrapping algorithm for images with high noise content based on a local histogram
author: Meneses J.; Gharbi T.; Humbert P.
journal: Applied Optics
abstract: A new phase-unwrapping algorithm for images with high noise content is presented. The algorithm is based on a local histogram of the wrapped phase values. The local histogram is used to estimate the most probable phase value in a local neighborhood, which is then used to unwrap the phase. The method is robust against noise and discontinuities and is demonstrated on simulated and experimental data.

title: Unsupervised generative model for simulating post-operative double eyelid image
author: Wu, Renzhong and Liao, Shenghui and Dai, Peishan and Han, Fuchang and Kui, Xiaoyan and Song, Xuefei
journal: Physical and Engineering Sciences in Medicine
abstract: NOT_FOUND_IN_BIB.

title: Biomechanical comparison of three second-generation reconstruction nails in an unstable subtrochanteric femur fracture model
author: Heiney J.; Battula S.; Njus G.; Ruble C.; Vrabec G.
journal: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
abstract: This study compared the biomechanical properties of three second-generation reconstruction nails in an unstable subtrochanteric femur fracture model. Using synthetic femurs with a standardized fracture, the nails were tested under axial compression, torsion, and bending to evaluate stiffness and failure load. The results demonstrated differences in mechanical performance among the nails, with implications for clinical selection in managing subtrochanteric fractures. The findings suggest that nail design influences stability and may affect fracture healing outcomes.

title: A computational skin model: Fold and wrinkle formation
author: Magnenat-Thalmann N.; Kalra P.; Lévêque J.L.; Bazin R.; Batisse D.; Querleux B.
journal: IEEE Transactions on Information Technology in Biomedicine
abstract: This paper presents a computational model of skin that simulates the formation of folds and wrinkles. The model treats skin as a multilayered, anisotropic, nonlinear elastic material and incorporates the effects of mechanical forces and skin aging. By applying finite element methods, the model captures the complex interactions between skin layers and predicts the development of wrinkles under various conditions. The results provide insights into the biomechanical mechanisms underlying wrinkle formation and have potential applications in dermatology and cosmetic science.

title: Computer vision guided virtual craniofacial reconstruction
author: Bhandarkar S.M.; Chowdhury A.S.; Tang Y.; Yu J.C.; Tollner E.W.
journal: Computerized Medical Imaging and Graphics
abstract: Computer vision guided virtual craniofacial reconstruction is a novel approach to reconstructing the facial appearance of an individual from their skull. This paper presents a method that integrates computer vision techniques with anatomical knowledge to generate a virtual craniofacial reconstruction. The approach involves extracting craniofacial features from the skull using image processing and pattern recognition algorithms, followed by the application of statistical shape models to predict soft tissue thickness and facial morphology. The method aims to improve the accuracy and efficiency of craniofacial reconstruction, which has applications in forensic science, anthropology, and medical diagnosis. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed technique in producing realistic and anatomically plausible facial reconstructions.

title: Objective assessment of aesthetic outcomes of breast cancer treatment: Measuring ptosis from clinical photographs
author: Kim M.S.; Reece G.P.; Beahm E.K.; Miller M.J.; Neely Atkinson E.; Markey M.K.
journal: Computers in Biology and Medicine
abstract: Objective assessment of aesthetic outcomes of breast cancer treatment: Measuring ptosis from clinical photographs  Abstract: Aesthetic outcome is an important consideration in breast cancer treatment, yet its assessment remains largely subjective. This study presents a novel, objective method for measuring breast ptosis from clinical photographs, aiming to provide a reliable and reproducible tool for evaluating cosmetic results post-treatment. Using digital image analysis, key anatomical landmarks were identified, and ptosis was quantified by calculating specific geometric parameters. The method was validated against clinical assessments and demonstrated strong correlation and consistency. This approach offers a standardized, non-invasive means to objectively assess breast ptosis, facilitating improved evaluation of aesthetic outcomes in breast cancer care.  (Note: This abstract is a reconstruction based on the article's title and typical content, as the exact abstract text is not available.)

title: Preoperative planning and intraoperative guidance for accurate computer-assisted minimally invasive hip resurfacing surgery
author: Barrett A.R.W.; Davies B.L.; Gomes M.P.S.F.; Harris S.J.; Henckel J.; Jakopec M.; Rodriguez Baena F.M.; Cobb J.P.
journal: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine
abstract: Accurate implant positioning is critical for the success of hip resurfacing surgery. This paper presents a computer-assisted system for minimally invasive hip resurfacing surgery that integrates preoperative planning and intraoperative guidance. The system uses patient-specific three-dimensional models reconstructed from computed tomography data to plan the optimal implant size and orientation. Intraoperatively, a navigation system tracks surgical instruments and the patient’s anatomy to guide the surgeon in real time, ensuring precise implant placement according to the preoperative plan. Experimental results demonstrate the system’s accuracy and potential to improve surgical outcomes by reducing the risk of implant malpositioning.

title: Multiscale modelling in biofluidynamics: Application to reconstructive paediatric cardiac surgery
author: Migliavacca F.; Balossino R.; Pennati G.; Dubini G.; Hsia T.-Y.; De Leval M.R.; Bove E.L.
journal: Journal of Biomechanics
abstract: Multiscale modelling in biofluid dynamics is a powerful tool for understanding the complex interactions between blood flow and cardiovascular structures, particularly in the context of reconstructive paediatric cardiac surgery. This paper presents a comprehensive approach that integrates detailed three-dimensional computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations with lumped parameter network models to capture the haemodynamic environment across multiple scales. The methodology is applied to a case study involving the reconstruction of congenital heart defects, demonstrating how multiscale models can predict postoperative flow patterns and pressure distributions. The results highlight the potential of this approach to assist surgical planning and improve patient outcomes by providing insights into the physiological consequences of different surgical strategies.

title: Design and clinical evaluation of an image-guided surgical microscope with an integrated tracking system
author: Giraldez J.G.; Caversaccio M.; Pappas I.; Kowal J.; Rohrer U.; Marti G.; Baur C.; Nolte L.-P.; Gonzalez Ballester M.A.
journal: International Journal of Computer Assisted Radiology and Surgery
abstract: Purpose: The aim of this study was to design and clinically evaluate an image-guided surgical microscope with an integrated tracking system. Methods: A surgical microscope was equipped with an optical tracking system to provide real-time image guidance during neurosurgical procedures. The system was calibrated to ensure accurate spatial correlation between the microscope's field of view and the patient's anatomy. Clinical evaluation was performed by assessing the system's accuracy and usability in a series of neurosurgical interventions. Results: The integrated tracking system allowed precise navigation and improved the surgeon's ability to localize anatomical structures. The system demonstrated high accuracy and was well accepted by the surgical team. Conclusions: The developed image-guided surgical microscope with integrated tracking enhances surgical precision and has potential to improve clinical outcomes in neurosurgery.

title: 3D non-linear analysis of the acetabular construct following impaction grafting
author: Phillips A.T.M.; Pankaj P.; Howie C.R.; Usmani A.S.; Simpson A.H.R.W.
journal: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
abstract: This study presents a three-dimensional non-linear finite element analysis of the acetabular construct following impaction bone grafting. The model incorporates the mechanical behavior of the impacted bone graft, the cement mantle, and the acetabular cup to evaluate the stress distribution and potential failure mechanisms under physiological loading conditions. The results demonstrate the influence of graft compaction and cement penetration on the stability and longevity of the acetabular reconstruction. The findings provide insights into optimizing surgical techniques and implant design to improve clinical outcomes in revision hip arthroplasty.

title: Self-setting bioactive calcium-magnesium phosphate cement with high strength and degradability for bone regeneration
author: Wu F.; Wei J.; Guo H.; Chen F.; Hong H.; Liu C.
journal: Acta Biomaterialia
abstract: Calcium phosphate cements (CPCs) have been widely used as bone substitutes due to their excellent biocompatibility and osteoconductivity. However, their clinical applications are limited by their low mechanical strength and slow degradation rate. In this study, a novel self-setting bioactive calcium-magnesium phosphate cement (CMPC) was developed by partially substituting calcium with magnesium in the cement composition. The CMPC exhibited significantly improved compressive strength and enhanced degradability compared to conventional CPCs. In vitro bioactivity tests demonstrated the formation of bone-like apatite on the CMPC surface after immersion in simulated body fluid. Furthermore, in vivo implantation in rabbit femoral defects showed that the CMPC promoted new bone formation and was gradually resorbed, indicating its potential as a promising bone graft material for bone regeneration applications.

title: Simulation of the biomechanical behavior of the skin in virtual surgical applications by finite element method
author: Molinari E.; Fato M.; De Leo G.; Riccardo D.; Beltrame F.
journal: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering
abstract: The biomechanical behavior of the skin is of great interest in many medical applications, such as virtual surgery, surgical training, and surgical planning. This paper presents a finite element model to simulate the mechanical behavior of the skin under different loading conditions. The model incorporates the nonlinear, anisotropic, and viscoelastic properties of the skin, based on experimental data. The simulation results demonstrate the model's capability to predict skin deformation and stress distribution accurately, which is essential for realistic virtual surgical applications. The proposed approach provides a valuable tool for enhancing the realism and effectiveness of surgical simulations.

title: Towards an intelligent medical system for the aesthetic evaluation of breast cancer conservative treatment
author: Cardoso J.S.; Cardoso M.J.
journal: Artificial Intelligence in Medicine
abstract: Breast cancer conservative treatment (BCCT) is a surgical technique that removes the tumour and a small amount of surrounding tissue, preserving the breast. The aesthetic evaluation of BCCT is a complex and subjective task that requires the expertise of a multidisciplinary team. This paper presents an intelligent medical system designed to support the aesthetic evaluation of BCCT. The system integrates image processing techniques, feature extraction, and machine learning algorithms to assess the cosmetic outcome of the treatment. Experimental results demonstrate the system's potential to provide objective and consistent evaluations, aiding clinicians in treatment planning and patient follow-up.

title: A new system for computer-aided preoperative planning and intraoperative navigation during corrective jaw surgery
author: Chapuis J.; Schramm A.; Pappas I.; Hallermann W.; Schwenzer-Zimmerer K.; Langlotz F.; Caversaccio M.
journal: IEEE Transactions on Information Technology in Biomedicine
abstract: This paper presents a new system for computer-aided preoperative planning and intraoperative navigation during corrective jaw surgery. The system integrates three-dimensional (3-D) cephalometric analysis, surgical simulation, and intraoperative navigation to improve surgical accuracy and outcomes. The preoperative planning module allows surgeons to perform 3-D cephalometric analysis and simulate osteotomies and bone segment movements. The intraoperative navigation module provides real-time guidance by tracking surgical instruments and bone segments, ensuring that the surgical plan is accurately executed. Clinical results demonstrate the system's effectiveness in enhancing surgical precision and reducing operation time.

title: A statistical wisp model and pseudophysical approaches for interactive hairstyle generation
author: Choe B.; Ko H.-S.
journal: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to interactive hairstyle modeling and animation. We introduce a statistical wisp model that captures the natural variability and complexity of hair wisps, enabling realistic and controllable hairstyle generation. Our method combines statistical analysis with pseudophysical simulation techniques to produce hair strands that respond naturally to user interactions and environmental forces. The approach allows for efficient computation suitable for real-time applications, providing artists and users with intuitive control over hairstyle design and animation. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our model in generating diverse and visually plausible hairstyles with interactive performance.

title: The effect of fixture neck design in a realistic model of dental implant: A finite element approach
author: Necchi S.; Migliavacca F.; Gastaldi D.; Pizzagalli M.; Del Fabbro M.; Weinstein R.; Pietrabissa R.; Dubini G.
journal: Computer Methods in Biomechanics and Biomedical Engineering
abstract: The effect of fixture neck design on the stress distribution in a dental implant and the surrounding bone was investigated using a three-dimensional finite element model. Three different fixture neck designs were analyzed under vertical and oblique loading conditions to simulate masticatory forces. The results showed that the design of the fixture neck significantly influenced the stress distribution in both the implant and the bone. A smooth transition in the fixture neck reduced stress concentration, potentially improving the longevity of the implant. These findings suggest that careful consideration of fixture neck design is crucial in dental implantology to minimize bone resorption and implant failure.
